file.content:
# Trivivo
"Trivivo" is a website developed by me that aims to test you with 15 questions of varying difficulty and topics, with staggering timeouts. The aim is to score the highest among the quiz-takers! ## Trello The Trello board is [here](https://trello.com/b/r301JdtS/trivivo). ## Project Structure ```text . ├── adminpanel ├── auth ├── game ├── kbc ├── static └── templates ``` - `adminpanel` app handles administrator actions of the app, allowing administrators to perform elevated actions such as CRUD operations, changing timeout speeds, etc. - `auth` app handles authentication of users/admins to various sites. - `game` app handles the game logic of the app, involving timeouts, progression to the next levels, score/leaderboard handling, etc. - `kbc` is the project folder (for Django projects). - `static` holds the staticfiles for the project & apps. - `templates` holds the templates for all the apps that get rendered when called via the `views.py` in each app. ## Issue Labels ### Quality | Label | Description | |---|---| | `accessibility` | Breaks keyboard or screen reader access | | `design` | CSS inconsistency, unfinished migration, or design debt | | `documentation` | Improvements or additions to documentation | ### Area | Label | Description | |---|---| | `auth` | Authentication or authorization related | | `backend` | Django / Python / view logic issue | | `database` | Model, query, migration, or index issue | | `frontend` | HTML / CSS / JavaScript issue | | `performance` | Causes excess queries, memory, or latency | ### Type | Label | Description | |---|---| | `bug` | Something is broken or behaving incorrectly | | `critical` | Crash, data loss, or auth bypass risk | | `security` | Vulnerability or exploitable behaviour | | `refactor` | Restructure code without changing behaviour | ### Dev | Label | Description | |---|---| | `infra` | CI/CD, GitHub Actions, or deployment configs | | `tests` | Missing, empty, or broken test coverage | ### Flow | Label | Description | |---|---| | `release` | Marks PRs intended to be merged into main (production) | ### Contribution | Label | Description | |---|---| | `enhancement` | New feature or request | | `help wanted` | Extra attention is needed | ### Triage | Label | Description | |---|---| | `duplicate` | This issue or pull request already exists | | `good first issue` | Good for newcomers | | `invalid` | This doesn't seem right |

content.text:
The repo currently has no open issues. A couple of things to clarify:

**What I can do:**
- Create issues in the `steadyfall/wwbm-webapp` repo with the labels defined in your README

**What I can't do:**
- Add issues to a GitHub Projects board — the MCP tools available don't expose GitHub Projects (v2) management. That requires GraphQL mutations not covered here.

**Options:**
1. I can create issues in the repo, and you can manually add them to your project board via the GitHub UI
2. If you use the `gh` CLI locally, I can run `gh project item-add` commands to add issues to a project board after creating them

Do you want me to go ahead and create issues? If so, what issues should I create? You can describe them or point me to your Trello board tasks and I can mirror them as GitHub issues.

message.content: Yes, go ahead and create issues from https://trello.com/b/r301JdtS/trivivo. Add appropriate labels to the issues as well. The issue title should be max 20 words and the description should be less than 400 words, structured.

content.thinking:
I got a good snapshot of the Trello board. Let me extract all the cards from the snapshot:

**Backlog:**
1. "Use LLM model from HuggingFace to generate questions for quiz app and record it directly to DB" - Label: Ambitious (blue), Priority: Low
2. "Checkout WebSockets for quiz session" - Label: Backend (orange), Priority: Medium
3. "Optimize model fields & decisions in `models.py`" - Label: Database (bold green), Priority: High
4. "Dockerize the application with `dev` image & `prod` image" - Label: Infra (bold yellow), Priority: Critical


5. "Change/refactor views' logic/functions in `views.py`" - Label: Backend (orange), Priority: High
6. "*Checkout/implement* `django-allauth`" - Label: Backend (orange), Priority: Medium
7. "Fix timer for questions and make it robust" - Label: Backend (orange), Priority: High
8. "Migrate all jQuery code to HTMX" - Label: Frontend (bold purple), Priority: Critical
9. "Make tests for checking features / simple functionality of the app" - Label: Testing (bold pink), Priority: Medium
10. "DEPLOY USING HOSTING AS A SERVICE / VPS / ANY OTHER" - appears to be cut off but looks like a deployment task with likely Critical priority and Infra label. Then there's switching from SQLite to PostgreSQL as a critical database priority, followed by an MVP script generation task that spans database and backend work. The frontend overhaul to Tailwind CSS and UI improvements for the game are both marked critical, while some earlier work like the management command refactor and grid background changes have already been completed.

Now I'm mapping the Trello labels to GitHub's label system—Backend, Database, Infra, and Frontend map directly, while Ambitious might translate to enhancement. For priority levels, I need to figure out how Critical and High map to GitHub's available labels, since the README defines area labels like auth, backend, database, frontend, and performance rather than explicit priority tiers. I'm mapping out the remaining card types to their GitHub labels—jQuery to HTMX gets `refactor` and `frontend`, test creation gets `tests`, deployment gets `infra`, the database migration gets `database`, the MVP script gets `database` and `backend`, and the frontend redesigns get `frontend` and `design`. Before I start creating issues, I should check the card descriptions to make sure I'm capturing the right details, though I'll aim to write structured descriptions under 400 words based on what the titles tell me. I'm also noting which cards to skip—the "Done" ones like the script rewrite don't need issues. I'm continuing through the remaining issues to create: WebSockets for real-time sessions, optimizing the models, dockerizing the app with separate environments, refactoring views, adding django-allauth authentication, and fixing the question timer reliability.

Then there's migrating jQuery to HTMX, writing core feature tests, deploying to a hosting service, switching from SQLite to PostgreSQL, generating an MVP dataset, and revamping the frontend design.

Before I create all these issues, I should verify which labels already exist on the GitHub repo—I might need to create some of them first if they're not there yet.

input.title: Use LLM from HuggingFace to generate quiz questions into DB
input.body:
## Summary
Integrate a HuggingFace LLM to automatically generate trivia questions and write them directly to the database, reducing manual data entry overhead.

## Motivation
Currently, questions are manually curated or loaded via scripts. An LLM pipeline would allow scalable, diverse question generation across topics and difficulty levels.

## Proposed Approach
- Select an appropriate open-source model from HuggingFace (e.g. instruction-tuned model like Mistral or Llama)
- Write a management command or script that prompts the model to generate questions in a structured format (topic, question, options, answer, difficulty)
- Parse and validate the model output
- Insert valid records directly into the `game` app's question models

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] A management command exists that invokes the HuggingFace model
- [ ] Generated questions match the required DB schema
- [ ] Invalid or malformed outputs are logged and skipped
- [ ] At least one topic/category is seeded end-to-end successfully

## Notes
- Consider rate limits, inference costs, and output quality
- May require a local inference setup or free-tier HuggingFace Inference API

input.title: Investigate WebSockets for real-time quiz sessions
input.body:
## Summary
Research and prototype WebSocket support to enable real-time communication during quiz sessions (e.g. live timers, answer sync, multiplayer potential).

## Motivation
The current quiz flow relies on HTTP polling or page reloads. WebSockets would allow the server to push timer updates and session state changes to the client instantly, improving responsiveness.

## Proposed Approach
- Evaluate Django Channels for WebSocket support
- Set up a basic ASGI configuration alongside the existing WSGI setup
- Prototype a consumer that broadcasts timer ticks and question progression
- Test against the existing `game` app session model

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Django Channels is evaluated and a decision is documented
- [ ] A working prototype WebSocket consumer exists
- [ ] Timer updates are pushed server-side rather than polled client-side
- [ ] No regression in existing game flow

## Notes
- Requires switching from WSGI to ASGI (Daphne or Uvicorn)
- Consider impact on deployment (hosting must support WebSockets)

content.text: {"id":"3929997269","url":"https://github.com/steadyfall/wwbm-webapp/issues/2"}

input.title: Optimize model fields and decisions in models.py
input.body:
## Summary
Audit and optimize database model definitions across the project — field types, constraints, indexes, and relationships — to improve data integrity and query performance.

## Motivation
Model definitions may have been written quickly during initial development. Reviewing them ensures appropriate field types (e.g. avoiding unnecessary `TextField` where `CharField` suffices), adding missing `db_index` hints, and enforcing constraints at the DB level.

## Scope
- Review all `models.py` files across `game`, `auth`, and `adminpanel` apps
- Check for missing `null`/`blank` consistency
- Identify fields that would benefit from indexing
- Remove redundant fields or consolidate where appropriate
- Verify `on_delete` behavior on all ForeignKey fields

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] All model fields have correct types and constraints
- [ ] Indexes are added where queries filter/order by a field
- [ ] A migration is generated and runs cleanly
- [ ] No data loss on applying the migration

## Notes
- Run `python manage.py migrate --check` to verify migration state before and after

content.text: {"id":"3929997404","url":"https://github.com/steadyfall/wwbm-webapp/issues/3"}

input.title: Dockerize application with separate dev and prod images
input.body:
## Summary
Containerize the application using Docker with distinct images for development and production environments to ensure consistent, reproducible deployments.

## Motivation
Without Docker, environment parity between dev and prod is fragile. Containerization eliminates "works on my machine" issues and simplifies CI/CD pipelines and future hosting options.

## Proposed Approach
- Write a `Dockerfile` with a multi-stage build: a `dev` stage and a `prod` stage
- `dev` image: includes dev dependencies, hot reload, debug toolbar
- `prod` image: slim base, gunicorn/uvicorn, no dev deps, collected static files
- Write a `docker-compose.yml` for local development (app + DB + optional Redis)
- Add a `docker-compose.prod.yml` override for production settings

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] `docker compose up` starts the app locally with no manual steps
- [ ] `prod` image builds successfully and serves via gunicorn
- [ ] Static files are collected in the prod image
- [ ] Environment variables are externalized via `.env` (not hardcoded)
- [ ] `dev` and `prod` images are clearly separated

## Notes
- This is a prerequisite for streamlined deployment

input.title: Refactor view logic and functions in views.py
input.body:
## Summary
Refactor the `views.py` files across the project to improve clarity, reduce duplication, and align with Django best practices (CBVs vs FBVs, proper mixins, etc.).

## Motivation
View logic may have grown organically, leading to fat views, duplicated permission checks, or inconsistent patterns. A targeted refactor will make views easier to maintain and extend.

## Scope
- Audit all `views.py` files across `game`, `auth`, `adminpanel`
- Extract repeated logic into mixins or utility functions
- Ensure consistent use of `LoginRequiredMixin` / `@login_required`
- Reduce view functions doing too many things (single responsibility)
- Standardize response patterns (redirect vs render vs JsonResponse)

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] No view function exceeds ~50 lines without clear justification
- [ ] Shared logic is deduplicated into mixins or helpers
- [ ] All existing tests (if any) still pass after refactor
- [ ] No behavioral changes to the user-facing flow

## Notes
- Coordinate with the timer fix issue to avoid conflicts on game views

input.title: Integrate django-allauth for authentication
input.body:
## Summary
Replace or augment the current custom auth flow with `django-allauth` to gain robust, extensible authentication including social login, email verification, and password management.

## Motivation
The current `auth` app handles authentication manually. `django-allauth` provides battle-tested implementations for registration, login, email confirmation, and OAuth providers, reducing maintenance burden.

## Proposed Approach
- Install and configure `django-allauth`
- Map existing user model to allauth's adapter
- Migrate existing login/register views to allauth's URL patterns
- Configure email backend for verification flows
- Optionally add at least one OAuth provider (e.g. Google)

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Users can register and log in via allauth
- [ ] Email verification flow works end-to-end
- [ ] Existing sessions/users are not broken by the migration
- [ ] Custom `auth` app views are deprecated or removed
- [ ] Admin panel still reflects authenticated users correctly

## Notes
- Review allauth's `ACCOUNT_*` settings carefully
- May require template overrides to match existing UI

input.title: Fix question timer to be robust and reliable
input.body:
## Summary
The per-question timer has known reliability issues. This issue tracks identifying the root cause and making the timer behave correctly under all conditions.

## Problem
The timer can desync, fail to expire correctly, or not reset properly between questions. This breaks the core game mechanic where timeouts affect scoring and progression.

## Proposed Fix
- Audit the current timer implementation (client-side JS vs server-side enforcement)
- Ensure the server validates question submission timestamps, not just client-side countdowns
- Handle edge cases: tab switching, slow network, rapid answer submission
- Prevent timer from running after a question is answered or game ends

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Timer counts down correctly for each question
- [ ] Expired timer triggers the correct timeout behavior server-side
- [ ] Timer resets cleanly when advancing to the next question
- [ ] No timer state leaks between game sessions

## Notes
- Related to the WebSockets investigation — a server-pushed timer would be more reliable
- Test with throttled network conditions in DevTools

content.text: {"id":"3929998945","url":"https://github.com/steadyfall/wwbm-webapp/issues/7"}

input.title: Migrate all jQuery code to HTMX
input.body:
## Summary
Replace the existing jQuery-based interactivity with HTMX to reduce JavaScript complexity, align with the Django template-driven architecture, and eliminate jQuery as a dependency.

## Motivation
jQuery adds unnecessary weight and encourages imperative DOM manipulation. HTMX enables declarative, server-driven interactions directly in HTML, which fits naturally with Django's template rendering model.

## Scope
- Audit all `static/` JS files and inline `<script>` blocks for jQuery usage
- Map each jQuery interaction to an HTMX equivalent (`hx-get`, `hx-post`, `hx-swap`, etc.)
- Add Django views or partials as needed to serve HTMX responses
- Remove jQuery from the asset pipeline once migration is complete

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] jQuery is fully removed from all templates and static files
- [ ] All existing dynamic interactions work correctly via HTMX
- [ ] No full-page reloads introduced where partial updates existed before
- [ ] Page bundle size is reduced

## Notes
- This is a critical refactor — test each interaction thoroughly
- HTMX version should be pinned in static or via a CDN with SRI hash

content.text: {"id":"3929999139","url":"https://github.com/steadyfall/wwbm-webapp/issues/8"}
{"id":"3929999248","url":"https://github.com/steadyfall/wwbm-webapp/issues/9"}

input.title: Write tests for core app features and functionality
input.body:
## Summary
Establish a test suite covering the core functionality of the `game`, `auth`, and `adminpanel` apps to prevent regressions and improve confidence in future changes.

## Motivation
The project currently lacks automated tests. Any refactor or new feature risks breaking existing behavior silently. A baseline test suite is essential before further development.

## Scope
- `game` app: session creation, question progression, timer expiry, scoring, lifelines
- `auth` app: registration, login, logout, access control
- `adminpanel` app: CRUD operations, admin-only access enforcement
- URL routing: verify all expected routes resolve correctly
- Model methods: test any custom `save()`, `clean()`, or property methods

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] `python manage.py test` runs without errors
- [ ] Coverage for happy paths on all core game flows
- [ ] At least one negative test per access-controlled view
- [ ] CI runs tests on every push (if CI is configured)

## Notes
- Use Django's built-in `TestCase` and `Client`
- Factory Boy or `mixer` may help with test data setup

content.text: {"id":"3929999501","url":"https://github.com/steadyfall/wwbm-webapp/issues/10"}

input.title: Deploy application to a hosting service or VPS
input.body:
## Summary
Deploy the Trivivo application to a publicly accessible hosting environment, making it available beyond local development.

## Motivation
The app is feature-complete enough for a public deployment. Getting it live enables real-user testing, feedback, and motivation for further development.

## Options to Evaluate
- **PaaS**: Railway, Render, Fly.io (easiest, managed infra)
- **VPS**: DigitalOcean Droplet, Hetzner (more control, manual setup)
- **Serverless-adjacent**: Vercel (limited for Django, not ideal)

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] App is accessible via a public URL
- [ ] Static files are served correctly (WhiteNoise or object storage)
- [ ] Environment variables are managed securely (not in version control)
- [ ] Database is persistent (not ephemeral)
- [ ] HTTPS is enabled
- [ ] `DEBUG=False` in production

## Notes
- Dockerizing the app first (see Dockerize issue) will simplify any VPS deployment
- Consider setting up a basic CI/CD pipeline to auto-deploy on merge to `main`

content.text: {"id":"3929999907","url":"https://github.com/steadyfall/wwbm-webapp/issues/11"}

input.title: Switch database from SQLite to PostgreSQL
input.body:
## Summary
Migrate the project's database backend from SQLite to PostgreSQL to support production-grade workloads, concurrent access, and more robust query capabilities.

## Motivation
SQLite is unsuitable for production deployments with concurrent users. PostgreSQL provides proper transaction isolation, full-text search, and is the standard for Django production deployments.

## Steps
1. Add `psycopg2-binary` (or `psycopg[binary]`) to dependencies
2. Update `DATABASES` setting in `settings.py` to use `django.db.backends.postgresql`
3. Externalize DB credentials via environment variables
4. Export existing SQLite data with `dumpdata` and import via `loaddata` into Postgres
5. Update `docker-compose.yml` to include a `db` service (if Dockerized)
6. Run all migrations against the new DB and verify

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] App runs correctly against a PostgreSQL database locally
- [ ] All existing migrations apply cleanly
- [ ] Data can be seeded from fixtures
- [ ] SQLite is no longer used in any environment
- [ ] DB URL is configurable via `DATABASE_URL` env var (use `dj-database-url`)

## Notes
- This is a prerequisite for production deployment

content.text: {"id":"3930000378","url":"https://github.com/steadyfall/wwbm-webapp/issues/12"}

input.title: Create management command to generate MVP dataset
input.body:
## Summary
Build a Django management command that generates and seeds the minimum viable dataset required to run the app end-to-end, replacing any ad-hoc scripts in `misc/data/`.

## Motivation
Setting up a fresh dev environment currently requires running scripts manually outside of Django's management layer. A proper management command is idempotent, documented, and fits naturally into the Django workflow.

## Proposed Approach
- Identify all data required for an MVP run: question categories, difficulty levels, sample questions, lifelines
- Write a `generate_mvp` management command in the `game` app
- Command should be idempotent (safe to run multiple times)
- Optionally support a `--reset` flag to wipe and re-seed

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] `python manage.py generate_mvp` runs without errors on a fresh DB
- [ ] The app is fully playable after running the command
- [ ] Command is idempotent
- [ ] Old scripts in `misc/data/` are removed or deprecated

## Notes
- This work is currently in progress
- Coordinate with the PostgreSQL migration to ensure compatibility

content.text: {"id":"3930000607","url":"https://github.com/steadyfall/wwbm-webapp/issues/13"}

input.title: Revamp frontend styling with TailwindCSS
input.body:
## Summary
Replace the current CSS approach with TailwindCSS utility classes across all templates to achieve a consistent, maintainable, and modern visual design.

## Motivation
The existing CSS is likely fragmented across multiple files with inconsistent naming and specificity issues. TailwindCSS enforces a design system through utility classes, speeds up iteration, and produces a smaller CSS bundle via PurgeCSS/JIT.

## Proposed Approach
- Install Tailwind via CDN (for quick start) or via the CLI/PostCSS pipeline
- Set up `tailwind.config.js` with content paths pointing to all Django templates
- Migrate templates one app at a time: `auth` → `game` → `adminpanel`
- Remove legacy CSS files once covered by Tailwind

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] All pages are styled using Tailwind utility classes
- [ ] Legacy CSS files are removed or replaced
- [ ] Tailwind is configured with a proper `content` glob (no unused classes in prod)
- [ ] Responsive design is maintained (mobile + desktop)
- [ ] Visual parity or improvement vs current design

## Notes
- This is actively in progress (12/14 checklist items complete on Trello)
- Coordinate with the game UI improvement issue

content.text: {"id":"3930000933","url":"https://github.com/steadyfall/wwbm-webapp/issues/14"}

input.title: Improve game UI for intuitiveness and user-friendliness
input.body:
## Summary
Redesign and improve the in-game UI to make the quiz experience more intuitive, engaging, and user-friendly for players of all familiarity levels.

## Motivation
The current game UI may lack visual hierarchy, clear feedback states, and interactive affordances. A better UI reduces confusion during gameplay and increases engagement.

## Areas to Improve
- **Question display**: clear typography, readable at a glance
- **Answer options**: obvious clickable targets with hover/active states
- **Timer**: visually prominent, changes color/urgency as time runs low
- **Lifelines**: clearly labeled, visually disabled when used
- **Score/progress**: visible at all times without cluttering
- **Feedback**: clear correct/incorrect states before advancing

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] All game states (question, answer reveal, timeout, game over) have distinct UI treatments
- [ ] Timer is visually prominent and urgency is communicated (e.g. color shift)
- [ ] Lifeline buttons are clearly differentiated (available vs. used)
- [ ] UI is tested on mobile and desktop viewports
- [ ] Accessibility: keyboard navigable, sufficient color contrast

## Notes
- This is actively in progress on Trello
- Coordinate with the TailwindCSS revamp — changes should use Tailwind classes

input.body:
## Summary
Replace the current CSS approach with TailwindCSS utility classes across all templates to achieve a consistent, maintainable, and modern visual design.

## Motivation
The existing CSS is likely fragmented across multiple files with inconsistent naming and specificity issues. TailwindCSS enforces a design system through utility classes, speeds up iteration, and produces a smaller CSS bundle via PurgeCSS/JIT.

## Proposed Approach
- Install Tailwind via CDN (for quick start) or via the CLI/PostCSS pipeline
- Set up `tailwind.config.js` with content paths pointing to all Django templates
- Migrate templates one app at a time: `auth` → `game` → `adminpanel`
- Remove legacy CSS files once covered by Tailwind

## Template Migration Checklist
- [x] templates/about.html
- [x] templates/base.html
- [x] templates/footer.html
- [x] templates/gameover.html
- [x] templates/leaderboard.html
- [x] templates/mainPage.html
- [x] templates/navbar.html
- [x] templates/question.html
- [x] templates/rules.html
- [x] templates/scoreboard.html
- [x] templates/authentication/signin.html
- [x] templates/gamerules.html
- [ ] templates/authentication/register.html
- [ ] templates/authentication/signout.html

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] All pages are styled using Tailwind utility classes
- [ ] Legacy CSS files are removed or replaced
- [ ] Tailwind is configured with a proper `content` glob (no unused classes in prod)
- [ ] Responsive design is maintained (mobile + desktop)
- [ ] Visual parity or improvement vs current design

## Notes
- This is actively in progress (12/14 checklist items complete on Trello)
- Coordinate with the game UI improvement issue
